solution:
\begin{soln}
  Differentiating the equation twice, we get that
  \[
    f''(7x+1)=f''(x)
  .\]

  Fix $x_0\in \mathbb{R}$ arbitrarily.
  Then define the sequence
  $\left\{ x_i \right\}_{i\ge 0}$ by
  $x_{n+1}=\frac{x_{n}-1}{7}$. Then note that
  \[
  \lvert x_{n+1}-x_{n} \rvert =\frac{1}{7}
  \lvert x_{n}-x_{n-1} \rvert
  .\]
  Therefore, by the condition of contractive sequence,
  $\left\{ x_{n} \right\}_{n\ge 0}$ converges. Checking gives
  that it converges to $- \frac{1}{6}$. (If you want to avoid
  contractive sequence, then you can define the sequence
  $y_n = x_{n}+\frac{1}{6}$ and then work with it.)

  Note that as $f''(7x+1)=f''(x)$, $f''(x_0)=f''(x_{n})$. Taking
  limits on both sides, we get that
  $f''(x_0)=f''(- \frac{1}{6})$. Since $x_0$ was fixed
  arbitrarily, $f''(x)=c$ for some constant $c\in \mathbb{R}$ 
  and all $x\in \mathbb{R}$.

  Since $f''(x)$ is continuous,
  integrating twice and checking gives that
   $f(x) = 3tx^2+tx+\frac{t}{12}$ is the only solution where
   $t$ is a fixed real constant.

   It is easy to check that this function indeed works and we
   are done.
\end{soln}
